Award.AwardTitle: Morphology of Young Core-Collapse Supernova Remnants from Multi-Physics Three-Dimensional Simulations
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support a theoretical investigation into the explosions of massive stars and how the properties of these stars can affect the early evolution of supernova remnants. Dr. Plewa and his students will develop and improve models that include neutrino-driven shock propagation, and will study the details of the explosion mechanisms and shock breakout. The principal goal of the work is to generate core-collapse supernova models in three dimensions to account for the most relevant physics and the geometry of mass flows between the core bounce and the early remnant phases.

Dr. Plewa will make models and data products available to the astrophysical community, which will be useful for other research groups. The work will involve many aspects of hydrodynamics, modeling of a wide range of physics, and high-performance computing. This group will continue efforts to provide outreach opportunities for undergraduate students, especially women and members of underrepresented groups, and to communicate results to the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
It is now established that core-collapse supernovae (SNe) and their remnants are characterized by asymmetric mass motion. The best observed objects, Cas A and SN 1987A, provide direct evidence of intrinsic asymmetries. Cas A is famous for its jet-like emission features and highly structured distribution of heavy elements. Especially the latter are believed to have originated from hydrodynamic instabilities which operate during the early SN explosion phases. A host of such instabilities is known at present, including the standing accretion shock instability (or SASI), and neutrino-driven convection, which both occur during about the first second of a supernova explosion, and which are followed by a subsequent, second round of instabilities of the Rayleigh-Taylor, Richtmyer-Meshkov and Kelvin-Helmholtz types on somewhat longer time scales. The best studied example in this respect is SN 1987A. Observational data of this event provides evidence for large scale mixing of nucleosynthetic products by the aforementioned processes that must have happened within the first minutes and hours of the supernova. Furthermore, high resolution speckle observations revealed the presence of a very fast moving localized emission feature that could possibly be interpreted as a bidirectional ejection of material, perhaps a weak jet.

The origins of mixing and asymmetries in core-collapse SNe are undoubtedly deeply rooted in the explosion mechanism. Shock revival due to neutrino heating of the postshock layers, decisively assisted by mass overturn due to the SASI and neutrino-driven convection, remain the primary mechanisms considered to be responsible for the explosion. In addition to hydrodynamic instabilities, both rotation and magnetic fields may also influence the morphology of the explosion and, in extreme cases, result in launching jets or highly collimated outflows. The rooting of the asymmetries in the early phases of the explosion, however, also implies that the subsequent evolution cannot be studied in complete isolation from the explosion's onset. In particular a proper understanding of the morphology and evolution of young core-collapse supernova remnants (ySNRs) cannot be achieved without taking at least the most relevant aspects of the very early explosion phases into account. Crucial in this respect is the proper modeling of the spectrum of hydrodynamic instabilities that appear in the SN problem, and their mutual interaction.

Enhancing the Proteus code (our developmental fork of the University of Chicago FLASH code) to the level required to be considered a core-collapse supernova code has not been a trivial undertaking. The major code development tasks required addressing challenges related to combining both multiple equations of state and multiple descriptions of the chemical composition. We also implemented a novel neutrino radiation transport method. The new algorithm uses the Isotropic Diffusion Source Approximation (IDSA) solver and is suitable for adaptive mesh simulations (AMR).

Mesh adaptive provides flexibility in terms of discrete representation of the solution and ultimately will allow for obtaining core-collapse supernova explosion models in a single simulation run from prior to collapse until when a young supernova remnant is formed. We note that on adaptively refined meshes, the number of cells in the simulation will grow during the remnant phase as an ever-increasing fraction of the domain develops complex flow features. We demonstrated that it is possible to mitigate this effect and control the runtime of the code by limiting the total number of zones in the domain. Here we extended this concept to a dynamically resized computational domain.
